newsitem.title: MALAWI: Malawi government, unions agree to strike talks.
newsitem.headline: Malawi government, unions agree to strike talks.

text.p: The Malawi government and unions have agreed to talks to end a five-week civil servant's strike over wages, national radio said on Thursday.

Chairman for the cabinet's committee on the economy, Cassim Chilumpha, told the radio the Civil Servants Trade Union (CSTU), Teachers Union of Malawi (TUM) and the Customs Workers Union (CWU), had agreed to talks in the capital Lilongwe.
He did not say when negotiations would begin.

"The position is indeed that the civil servant's trade union, plus customs workers union and teachers union of Malawi, have agreed between themselves that time is ripe now for them to come to meet government," Chilumpha said.
"And we have accepted their wish for dialogue...," he added.
Malawi's civil servants are demanding a 100 percent salary increase recommended by an independent commission two years ago.
The government, however, says such an increase for its 100,000 workers will disrupt the economy, forecast to grow by seven percent in 1997, two percent less than last year.
Instead, it has agreed to raise salaries for the lowest paid worker by 47 percent and 10 percent for management.
